Bob, you have essentially said that you can only recognize monetary value. What you are looking to do is to find a way to assign a valuation to an intangible asset--an accounting problem. Surely you can think more expansively than your accountant!

I can't possibly "sell" you on the "non-monetary value" of my humanities education. I can however make the following points:

I learned to see equally from multiple points of view.
I learned that the complexity of a fully engaging experience of art is attractive and transformative.
I learned to be comfortable in situations of ambiguity.
I learned to make an infertile field bear fruit. (I learned to see beneath the surface.)
I learned to view and apply local human activities in a larger context.
I learned that the "sale" is made when one is completely involved in an artistic response, and not when one is given a "pitch" to evaluate dispassionately.
And finally, I learned from my own fiction writing that active creativity tends to open us to connections that are otherwise closed or overlooked.

These nonmonetary lessons have allowed me to make better financial and career decisions, although that was not your question.
@ Craig Avery: Hear, hear!

Bob,

As an undergrad in the early '90's I doubled majored in Economics and Art History.

I knew I wanted a business career, and the Econ checked the "meat and potatoes" box enough for me to be confident I'd be employable. I've since had a career in operations, technology and finance, got an MBA, and do mergers and acquisitions for a living.

But while Econ set the stage in many ways, my Art History and other humanities courses have been incredibly valuable to me professionally. I go back to the humanities mindset whenever I engage with the whole "creative" side of business - product design, marketing, HR, even engineering (try telling programmers they're not creative!). If paintings and novels are tools for communicating and influencing, then training in the humanities helps us understand how they work. Today, I can have a conversation with Marketing where I ask "what's the ROI on this campaign going to be" but I can also give informed feedback on design, fit to brand, and so on. My finance-only colleagues typically have to sit that one out.

While I am professionally more versatile for having studied the arts, I believe I'm also happier. I can have great conversations with a wide range of colleagues delving into their fields with more informed curiosity. I get excited to think about people's motivations and psychology, so important to the human endeavor of Management. This is practical but also just plain fun, stimulating, gratifying, and meaningful.

We tend to agree that there isn't much to be gained from taking a humanities course other than checking off credits towards graduation.  Sell us on the value to our lives!  I believe a non-monetary value exists but don't comprehend it.  Do that and maybe the money would follow.

The low paid may seem to do better but whatever they buy goes up too.  The unions, like Obama, only care about themselves. While a $2 or so increase might seem insignificant to someone who has never run a business (like Krugman and Obama), it adds up and really hurts businesses who often make only a penny profit on every dollar received.

Businesses like In-N-Out have been paying their workers decent wages all along. They've not only made money all along, but they've expanded, too. The same is true of Costco, whose employees average $22 per hour or more, and receive benefits. Sam's Club, their direct competitor, could do the same.

When you think about it isn't it just a wee bit absurd that the idea of increasing the minimum wage just prove so controversial?  Shouldn't we really be arguing about the imposition of a maximum wage (i.e., a salary cap), and not just on a handful of professional sports figures?  If a CEO at Walmart is earning, say, one-hundred times as much money as one of the company's stock boys, shouldn't he/she be working 100 times as hard?  Yes, I'm aware that our system of capitalism-gone-mad isn't going to provide a remedy for this situation, not even at the IRS' "income redistribution" clearing-house. Still, the debate over the minimum wage looks pretty ridiculous when you place it in its proper context.

Dr. Krugman doesn't provide the specifics, but here is one: two towns, about 10 miles apart, one in Washington state, one in Idaho. Washington raised their minimum wage level significantly higher than the Federal minimum wage. Predictions were that the stores on the Idaho side of the border would directly benefit, as they could pay their workers significantly less. In fact, the stores in Idaho mostly lagged or even went out of business. The Washington side, on the other hand, has thrived and is doing exceedingly well! Workers fight for jobs on the Washington side, allowing employers be selective in hiring (and leaving poor quality workers to handle the Idaho jobs). More money in the pockets of Washington side workers resulted in greater spending and demand on the Washington side, which was followed by greater expansion and revenue to the community.

It's ironic that you claim we can fix the problem by simply "buying American" while defending Walmart, a firm which specializes in selling us the cheapest made products possible, almost all made outside the U.S. Perhaps if they paid their employees more, the employees would be buying more products allowing Walmart to sell more better-quality products...products made in the U.S.!

The noise was toned way down for that video. Bets?

Are they going to make quiet ones. Are people beating a path to the doors of makers of quiet leaf blowers, sound systems, DJ services,and motorcycles?

Reliability and safety issues aside, I'd like to see some discussion about the noise. Current drones (including the one shown in the promotional video) emit an annoying sound. Even if they were required to traverse designated industrial/commercial corridors for the bulk of their routes, they would ultimately need to enter neighborhoods and yards to deliver their payload. It brings to mind dozens (or hundreds) of tiny leaf blowers hovering just above otherwise tranquil spaces. Further, plans to mitigate the noise impact would probably involve trade-offs like delivering all at once (super noisy, short period) or staggering deliveries (relatively quiet, but constant and unavoidable throughout the day).

Of course, perhaps there are quieter versions of the technology in existence. Someone please enlighten us if that's the case.

To date, I have found Pope Francis inspiring and refreshing. Francis's compassion for the poor and the marginalized is evident in his words and deeds, and is an example to Catholics and non-Catholics alike. Last week's Apostolic Exhortation challenged the excesses of laissez-faire capitalism and strongly endorsed ecumenicism-- both needed and uplifting themes.

If Francis is successful in his campaign to help the poor and the marginalized, he will have achieved a great thing. He will also have achieved much if he helps to increase ecumenical understanding. I will consider Francis's papacy a resounding success if these goals are realized, even if he is unable to take on additional reforms.

I believe the "overwhelming public support" Dr. Krugman mentions is very real, even in a state like Maine, or especially here, depending on who you talk to.

The very simple fact of the matter is that in fast-food, for instance, it is branding that drives customers to particular restaurants, not price. And it greed which makes these owners pay their employees so little.

Anecdotally, I know of two businesses that pay their employes far above the minimum wage, plus benefits, and have not suffered for doing so. The often-spoken of "power of the market" has very little to do with many small businesses, except when they are threatened by monopolistic competitors using rent-seeking and other devices to crush competitors. .

Since minimum wage workers are, almost by definition, not unionized, it seems rather bizarre to assert that increasing the minimum wage is an evil plot by unions.

But then, the idea that there is a "free market" just existing out there is the centerpiece of a fairly bizarre (and disturbingly influential) economic cult currently obsessing many Americans. Those Americans should read a little economic history, starting perhaps in the Middle Ages: markets were _made_, very intentionally, and transactions rushed to them not because they were _free_, but exactly because they were _regulated_. In a truly 'free' market, your exchange partner can pull out a gun near the end and take both the money and the goods. An aggressive actor can drive all competitors out of business and then jack up prices. A few players can collude….and many other distortions that make free, unregulated markets extremely unattractive to most buyers and sellers.

Our system is set up for hostility between business and labor. US business has planted itself in firm opposition to unions. Their PR firms, disguised as think tanks and media pundits, have convinced voters to think that greedy, corrupt unions will ruin US corporations if not kept down.

But I’ve read that in other countries, such as Germany, unions & business actually cooperate. Unions know they’re respected not vilified, and their reps sit on the boards of large companies.

Feeling more secure, they will compromise in negotiations over pay, especially during recessions. Govt and business protect workers with job stability but shorter hours during downturns, This is both humane and smart, since it avoids mass layoffs and long term joblessness, which poison the US workers' security and living standards.

In a society like ours, where unions are vilified, most workers feel realistically they're under threat. This keeps increasing the hostility between business and employees.

The examples from abroad are like from a different planet. Maybe with space travel, we could acquaint ourselves with their sensible solutions!

THE authoritarian Chinese government, is also very good at limiting the amount of information available about disasters in China. There was no Anderson Cooper allowed in the earthquake zone after the quake. I saw the soldiers attempting to locate survivors there, but when the CCTV news crews turned off their cameras, the soldiers stopped working.

I saw villagers living in makeshift shelters, tents too, donated by foreign governments.

It took soldiers 16 to 24 hours to walk to sites were the damage was extensive. CCTV said it was because the weather was too bad for helicopters, but key government officials managed to arrive from Beijing within in 8 hours...guess the weather wasn't too much of a risk for them.

Now that cities have been rebuilt, the history of the 2008 earthquake has been redone as well. I suppose you could categorize this as another benefit of an authoritarian government.

Since typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines I've been waiting for the media to comment on the differences between the Philippine government's reaction in contrast with that of the Chinese government after the Sichuan earthquake. One finally came.

Hours after the earthquake, Chinese soldiers arrived on location after walking, sometimes on hands and knees because roads were destroyed, to rescue those buried under the rubbles. Then came the helicopters and massive amount of government rescue goods. I was also impressed by how quickly pre-fabricated temporary houses (not tents) were set up for the victims.

In the Philippines days later we haven't seen any military personnel on site. Finally TV images showed some uniformed people appeared. A few were Philippine soldiers, with guns. They were there to guard the stores to prevent looting, not helping the victims. Then the American soldiers and international rescuers showed up with supplies. Given that this typhoon had a few days' warning of its disastrous power and that typhoons are regular occurrences in the Philippines, there is no excuse for the slow response.

Authoritarian government such as China has its problems. But we have to admit that they are efficient when they determined to accomplish something. After watching the Red Army soldiers' selfless devotions and the government's quick resolution to rebuild the area, I almost forgive them for fighting my side of soldiers in the bloody civil war of the 40's.
